#Text=Interview with Sue Gardner of the Wikimedia Foundation
#Text=This article mentions the Wikimedia Foundation , one of its projects , or people related to it .
#Text=Wikinews is a project of the Wikimedia Foundation .
#Text=Wednesday , October 24 , 2007
#Text=Wikinews reporters interviewed Sue Gardner , an employee of the Wikimedia Foundation , the project that runs Wikipedia and several other projects , including Wikinews .
#Text=Before coming to Wikimedia , she ran CBC . CA , the website of Canada 's national public broadcaster .
#Text=She was also a radio and television journalist for 10 years .
#Text=Interview
#Text=Matt : Hi Sue , could you explain what you do for the Wikimedia Foundation ?
#Text=Sure .
#Text=I am a consultant & special advisor to the board .
#Text=Essentially , I am here to help the organization professionalize and improve .
#Text=It 's a young organization with a lot of normal ' young-organization ' challenges — and I am here to help fix them .
#Text=What was your job position for cbc . ca , and what did you work on while you were there ?
#Text=I was senior director of CBC . CA .
#Text=( That means I ran it . )
#Text=Do you want me to explain a little about what it is ?
#Text=Dodge : Please do

#Text=It 's the website of the Canadian public broadcaster , the only national public broadcaster in Canada and the equivalent to the BBC , the Australian Broadcasting Corporation , the French pubcaster . etc.
#Text=CBC is mainly a news organization , and CBC . CA is mainly a news website .
#Text=How did you come to work for the Wikimedia Foundation ?
#Text=Were you asked to join by someone ?
#Text=And if so , who ?
#Text=I actually first got interested in the Wikimedia Foundation in a serious way , when I saw it do such a good job on the Virginia Tech story .
#Text=On the morning of the Virginia Tech massacre , I was following the story on Wikipedia/Wikinews , and reading the talk page .
#Text=And it was a really excellent level of conversation that was being had there .
#Text=I was really seriously impressed .

#Text=So I started doing a little reading about the organization , which resulted in me talking with Brad Patrick [ then General Counsel to the Board of Trustees ] and then Florence [ Nibart-Devouard , Chair of the Board ] .
#Text=Which resulted in me coming here .
#Text=Brian :
#Text=In joining WMF was there anything you brought from CBC . ca 's policies that you feel have influenced your contributions to the foundation ?
#Text=Can you give Wikinews any tips ?
#Text=I am assuming their similar balance/neutrality policies as the BBC 's
#Text=Yes , I think so .
#Text=CBC is an extremely thoughtful , intentional , deliberate organization .
#Text=I have borrowed from it liberally thus far — our code of conduct owes something to the CBC 's , as does our travel policy , travel approvals policy , reimbursement policy etc.
#Text=So there are a lot of new policies here ( and there will be more ) that have been heavily influenced by the CBC .
#Text=In terms of journalistic policy , I have had no influence on how Wikinews handles things .
#Text=And Brian , you are correct that CBC 's editorial policies are very similar to those of the BBC .
